isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS - DIAGNOSTIC ANALYIS PROCEDURES FOR LUBE OIL IN FUEL

svcproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC ANALYIS PROCEDURES FOR LUBE OIL IN FUEL

step1.para: If lube oil is suspected to be in the fuel, drain some fuel from the filter and observe its color. If the fuel appears darker than it should, it is recommended a small amount of fuel to be purchased from the supplier for comparison to confirm contamination.

If comparing fuels is impossible or inconclusive, remove the fuel filter and cut the housing open using a filter cutter. If the filter element appears black, oil may have entered the fuel system. The point of entry is most likely past an injector "O" ring or a missing "O" ring.
Disconnect the high pressure lube oil hose at the high pressure lube oil pump.
Connect a regulated air supply to the disconnected high pressure lube oil hose.
Apply 100 PSI air pressure with the regulated air supply. This will pressurrize the entire oil manifold.
Inspect for air leakage around each injector assembly.
Remove fuel lines from the fuel manifold and check for air leakage.
If leakage is observed at an injector, remove and inspect the injector for obvious damage or worn O-rings.

If no leakage is present, perform Injector "Buzz" Test while the air pressure is still being applied to the oil manifold. Oil discharge from each injector should be equal. If an injector or injectors show excessive oil discharge in comparison to others it is suspect. If it is not possible to determine which injector(s) are suspect, apply air pressure using a cylinder leak tester and observe leakage during an Injector "Buzz" Test.
If no leakage is evident, remove all injectors and inspect all "O" rings on each injector.

item.para: Discard all "O" rings after inspection. Always use new "O" rings when reinstalling injectors.
After reassembly, drain fuel tanks and dispose of contaminated fuel properly.
